subject: Spring in Santa Fe
event:
Ah, spring in Santa Fe... what could be more beautiful... the skies are blue, the days are warm, everything in blooming... especially the damn juniper, which is why my eyes are red and itchy, my nose is stuffed up, and I keep sneezing.  Of course, I can just pop a benadryl, and alleviate all my symptoms.  That is, if I don't mind turning into a zombie and sleeping away most of the day.  

Which I can't afford to do, because this is my favorite time of year for another reason as well.  Yes, boys and girls, it's TAX TIME!  No, of course, I don't do my own taxes.  I have a wonderful accountant who does them for me, which is a good thing, because my return looks like the Manhattan telephone directory these days.  Of course, it still takes me a week bent over little bits of paper to get all my records organized enough to give to my accountant.  Every year I swear I'm going to try and keep everything better organized and current, so that tax time is not such a bloody headache... and every year I don't.

As a good liberal, I don't actually object to paying taxes (although I would rather they spent more of my money on schools and health care and the space program, and less on bombs and tanks and Halliburton)... but I hate having to deal with all the record keeping.  Sometimes the tide of little bits of paper threatens to submerge me entirely.  I do find myself envying the folks who get a refund... but not nearly as much as I envy the ones who can still use the short form of blessed memory.

Oh, well.  This too will pass, the same way it does every year.  And the pollen count will go back down again... until the chamisa starts to bloom, at least.

comments.article:
You should try being in Mississippi, Louisiana, Alabama, or Georgia this time of year!

Imagine, if you will, waking up one bright spring morning, walking outside to bring in the garbage can from the curb, and noticing that it is foggy this morning...

...wait. This fog is YELLOW?

Oh, crap. Its pine tree mating season again.

:(
And Arkansas. :(

As a good conservative, I'm very happy to pay my taxes to keep our communities thriving, but I hate all the niggling paperwork, too.  I heard a glorious rumor about a decade ago that we were going to become a paperless society.  Please, now!

I've been sitting around with my friends talking out short stories that we all wrote and your name has been mentioned sevearl times for reference and I love you.

I love fantasy/science fiction but its all shit. SHIT! Except for like, your stuff. Its so freaking good.

You're a human who has allergies and lives in Arizona or something and like fan/writer relationships are so weird, but I want to make you know that like Tyrion is a real human being that I've experienced. And even though it sucks that you write in a genre and people will think less of you. Your work is timeless.
You just take as long as you freaking need to write your damn books. I'll wait patiently.

comments.upictitle: Jerusha: toshi x x japan yoshiki reunion
comments.article: But the days aren't warm right now! They were last week, though.  And yeah, the juniper is driving me crazy.

although I would rather they spent more of my money on schools and health care and the space program, and less on bombs and tanks and Halliburton

Seconded! And this might be a reason why I agree.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h39JTiutMWk

Of course it's a news parody, but the people are real. >.<

Anyway.
Yay for Spring, and boo for allergies.
Good luck with your taxes. =D

Try paying taxes in Canada! As an international student, I can't legally be employed and so I don't... but I've seen what friends are paying, and OUCH! I'm sort of not looking forward to THAT aspect of permanent residence. I just consider it an Awesome Tax - a fee we pay for getting to live in Canada. :-) (can you tell I like it here?)

Canadian taxes may be higher, but at least you get health care.

To really compare US and Canadian tax rates, you need to add in everything we pay for health care. And that's only if you don't actually get sick. God forbid you ever really get sick in America. We have great doctors and hospitals, but paying for them will wipe out even the most affluent. Of course, there's insurance... but more and more, that only seems to be available for young people with no health problems.
comments.subject: taxes in Canada

comments.article:
As a good liberal, I don't actually object to paying taxes

The taxes are one thing (and the things they get used for are yet another), but the thing that really frosts me is the level of hassle and intrusiveness. And the knowledge, as you are going through this process, that some faceless bureaucrat has the ability to put you through hell (audit) if he doesn't like what he sees.

The idea of a revenue-neutral shift from taxing income to taxing pollution (most recently proposed by Gore at his Congressional testimony) is interesting for what it could do for the environment, and for employment. But escaping from the annual IRS ritual would be one hell of a nice bonus.

As far as I know, Gore isn't proposing eliminating the income tax. The pollution tax would be in addition to the standard income tax.

If he or another liberal candidate was elected, hopefully there would be more audits of large international conglomerates and less of private individuals.

Pollen is out in full force in NC as well. I have a friend that refers to it as Tree Bukake.

I get thi great stuff from a local woman that is Aloe Gel, Peppermint and menthol crystals. It works great on sore muscles and cleans out your sinus's. I have a new bottle I bought to give my PT and then I haven't met up with her. If you think it would help you I can send it in your direction when I finally get home on Tuesday. Or I can send you to her website. It's www.purelysoap.com. you have to order the pepermint spray and in comments request the gel. I have no affiliation with the lady that makes it except that it has kept me moving ad breathing when otherwise I wouldn't have. My massage therapist introduced me to ger products.

I should not comment at nearly 4 AM so please excuse typos. I'm in upstate NY for my grandma's funeral now, we made it here before she died. Now no sleep for a week plus airplane germs plus whatever else I feel like death. I think I have a fever plus swollen glands plus aches and pains. I am much too young to be this broken.

Peace.

Tobi (aka wolfden tho i can't seem to log in right now)
claritin is your friend!

I also would suggest chlorpheniramine. You can take it with Claritin and it works for 4-6 hours. It is actually non-drowsy.
I teach, so being a zombie is not a good idea when small children are running around the classroom.
You are lucky (??) that your accountant lets you wait so long to give him your notes.  If we don't have all the numbers in by March 15, our accountants start calling...every hour or so.
Given the telephone book of slips of paper he has put together, the accountant has probably booked a week for him months in advance for him.  Maybe he even booked it last year!

Uncle Sam hits everyone in some way. I myself now get to use the short form again. I guess if you have nothing, you don't have to claim anything. Since I sold my home and moved for work, I now rent an apartment, both my children moved out, and my piddly-ass job doesn't allow me to raise to a higher tax bracket, my taxes have become rather simple.

My advice for easy tax preparation is to have nothing. It makes life, (at least at tax time,) much easier.

I highly recommend Claratin - I am strongly affected by allergy meds, especially anything with pseudoephedrine, and it royally messes me up. Claratin, however, works wonders, and one lasts all day. I couldn't visit my parents' house without it!
comments.subject: Here's my sagebrush pollen grain for you...

comments.article: I like Claritin too, but I used to be on Zyrtec and I liked that much better.  But, that was like $35 a month on my current insurance plan, the Claritin is like $6. :/  It works well enough though that I haven't had a lot of complaints.

comments.article:
You could do as a character in the movie Stranger Than Fiction did. She only paid the taxes she agreed with. So if you don't agree with the defense spending you don't pay whatever percentage of the budget that goes into defense spending.

Of course this might be just about guaranteed to get you audited by the IRS.
I was thinking the same thing. :)

Spring here has come early and warm, and those iggy widdle birch pollen are everywhere.

4-6 weeks of hell, despite chromoglycine acid spray and double doses of Loratandin. I should try to get my hands on Benadryl since I'm a zombie anyway these days.

allergies and taxes are just two of the unsung heroes of spring

have you tried flonase? it's worked miracles for me. the only thing that's worked,actually. especially if you combine it with claritin!

My accounts are, I daresay, rather less complex than yours, but I've still hired outside help to do my taxes the last few years, since I've been getting about half my total income from writing. This change coincided with my marriage, roughly, and my wife is a bit irked that, since we're filing jointly now, she never gets a refund anymore. As for me, it's paying the estimated quarterly taxes that I hate the most, mostly since it means thinking about taxes four times a year instead of just once...

As an American who became a Canadian citizen as soon as dual citizenship was allowed (by the US, Canada was willing), I no longer pay taxes in the US - but I do have to file a form with the US feds every year, for no good reason that I can see! The really fun thing, though, is every couple of years when the California State Franchise Board writes to me and says "we note you earned x this year, but you didn't pay our taxes, how come?" I always feel like replying that if they looked at the address to which they were writing, they'd not that, oh, it's not in California! Not to mention the fact that in Quebec I pay literally nine times what I'd pay in California (I calculated it once) - certainly I'd rather pay the CA taxes if I could. Because I work for a guy in California in a freelance job, the CA people get all confused. My accountant seems to be the only one who understands it all, really!

Snow's melting here, btw, and I'm told green shoots are beginning to emerge - I've been housebound for a month after foot surgery, so am missing the glorious early Spring here, alas!

I never had allergies growing up, but I started to develop them in college (1990); back then I would take some OTC thing once or twice in the spring and once or twice in the fall.  By early 2004 I was taking a 24-hr Claritin every day all year and it wasn't enough.  I was getting sick all the time, and putting on weight.  I started seeing my wife's acupuncturist in Feb 04 and by May I was taking her herbal remedies occasionally when I needed to.  She can clear most allergies very simply in 24 hours (not all of them at once, you have to pick something or groups of similar somethings per treatment).  Trained as a scientist I was very skeptical but it has been an absolute miracle for me.
comments.subject: Tried Acupuncture?

comments.article: I feel your pain. Zyrtec D is pretty much amazing, but it can only do so much.
I'm so jealous!
comments.subject: Boy, do I miss new mexico

comments.article:
It never ceases to amaze me that after several thousand years of evolution us humans still get reduced to snivelling wrecks by a few flowers.

I never seemed to suffer from pollen until my late teens, and now every year it's regular as clockwork. End of March, start of spring, BANG, hayfever and 3-4 weeks of zombie-like state. Then it goes away for a while. Then it comes back.

Fun.

I've yet to find decent medication for it.

Filing is always really simple for me.  My friend is a cpa and she only charges me $35.  I got my state and federal returns the other day and now I'm about 15 comic books and one Xbox 360 richer.  ^_^
just sayin'
comments.subject: It's inevitable, you know

comments.article:
I commiserate on both counts: tax and allergy. The changes in the complexity of my tax situation is a wash for me, because I used to have to file 1040NR, but I can file the EZ kind. Now, I can file regular 1040 based on substantial presence, but I also own a house, so I have to use itemized deduction. Still, I know I have nothing to complain about because I don't have a tenth of the complexity of your tax situation.

For allergies, I use (1) Claritin (2) prescription strength anti-allergy eye drops and (3) an anti-histamine nosespray. On bad days, which are coming, I need all 3 to remain functional. So far this year, I've gotten away with just Claritin or just the eye drop. It'll be worse before it'll be better. Yay.
